name: clear-cutting, primary forest to arable land, forest, intensive | land tenure, arable land, measured as carbon net primary productivity, forest, intensive | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19980/documentation

This dataset represents the interventions associated with the clear-cutting of primary forest for the provision of arable land tenure, annual crop. NPP (net primary productivity of a given land, in kg C / m2 and year) and VEG (above-ground biomass, below-ground biomass and dead organic matter) values are parameterized. ;VEG values and production volumes are derived from the Appendix S1 and S2 of Novaes et al. 2017. The most updated data is available in www.cnpma.embrapa.br/forms/BRLUC.php. In this reference, VEG values of primary forests and grassland were estimated based in Brazil, 2016 and croplands, pasture man made and forest intensive VEG values based in European Commission, 2010 and weighted according to climate categories occurrence per state. NPP values are reported by Haberl et al. (2007) and the average value for Latin America is adopted. The types of exchanges and their emission factors are the same from land transformations datasets 'clear-cutting, primary forest to arable land, annual crop, BR, 2010 - 2015' and 'land already in use, annual cropland to annual crop, BR, 2010 - 2015' available in Ecoinvent database (Rossi, 2017a,b), which in turn were retrieved from Andrea & Merlet (2001).;Bibliography is listed below:;- Andrea, M.O., Merlet, P. (2001). Emission of trace gases and aerosols from biomass burning. Global Biogeochemical Cycles. V 15, N4, p.955-966.;- Brazil (2016). Third National Communication of Brazil to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change âEURO“ Volume III. Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation, BrasÃ­lia.;- European Commission (2010) Comission decision of 10 June 2010 on guidelines for the calculation of land carbon stocks for the purpose of Annex V to Directive 2009/28/EC. European Union, Brussels.;- Haberl H, Erb KH, Krausmann F, Gaube V, Bondeau A, Plutzar C, Gingrich S, Lucht W, Fischer-Kowalski M. 2007. Quantifying and mapping the human appropriation of net primary production in earth's terrestrial ecosystems. PNAS. v104 n31: 12942-12947.;- Jungbluth, N. et al. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Bioenergy. ecoinvent report No. 17. Dubendorf, CH: Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories.;- Krausmann, F., Erb, K. H., Gingrich, S., Lauk, C., & Haberl, H. (2008). Global patterns of socioeconomic biomass flows in the year 2000: A comprehensive assessment of supply, consumption and constraints. Ecological Economics, 65(3), 471-487.;- Novaes RML, Pazianotto RA, Brandao M, Alves BJR, May A, Folegatti-Matsuura MIS. 2017. Estimating 20-year landuse change and derived CO2 emissions associated with crops, pasture and forestry in Brazil and each of its 27 states. Glob Change Biol. 23:3716âEURO“3728 .doi.org/10.1111/gcb.13708;- Rossi V, 2017a, clear-cutting, primary forest to arable land, annual crop, BR, Undefined, ecoinvent database version 3.3. Accessed in September, 2017;- Rossi V, 2017b, land already in use, annual cropland to annual crop, annual crop, BR, Undefined, ecoinvent database version 3.3. Accessed in September, 2017

This activity starts with the natural state of primary forest.

The dataset includes the carbon stored in Above-Ground Biomass (AGB), Below-Ground Biomass (BGB) and Dead Organic Matter (DOM) pools. It includes the fluxes from these carbon pools in terms of CO2 and other trace gases caused by the burning of biomass. It also includes a rough estimation for the machine use required for the clear-cutting, with emissions and ocupation exchanges based in an European model. 
The loss/gain of Soil Organic Carbon (SOC) usually associated with a land tranformation is accounted for in the downstream activity using the arable land tenure, given that it depends on the subsequent land use practice. 
This activity ends with the provision of arable land tenure, measured in unit kg carbon Potential Net Primary Production (NPP0).
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/021:Silviculture and other forestry activities/0210:Silviculture and other forestry activities

processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
From the data of Novaes et al., 2017, the only extrapolation is the convertion of land transformation scenarios into production volumes and its uncertainty values. More details about this can be found in the PV_comment.

Exchanges emission factors are the same from land transformations datasets 'clear-cutting, primary forest to arable land, annual crop, BR, 2010 - 2015' (Rossi, 2017a) and 'land already in use, annual cropland to annual crop, BR, 2010 - 2015' (Rossi, 2017b), thus extrapolated from a national level to state level.

exchanges.description: Yield = 1.0 kg C NPP/ha - Land that is made available for the cultivation of forest, intensive, expressed in kg carbon net primary productivity

flow.name: land tenure, arable land, measured as carbon net primary productivity, forest, intensive
flow.category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/02:Forestry and logging/021:Silviculture and other forestry activities/0210:Silviculture and other forestry activities

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value: VEG / NPP / 0.47 (ratio C to biomass*) * 0.88 (fraction burned**) * CF (Combustion Factor of biome***) * EmissionFactor 

The share of VEG that is burned is multiplied with the emission factor.

*Brazil (2016, Tab A1.7, p.244) presents the value of 47% for all carbon pools considered in forests (AGB, BGB, DOM) for Brazilian forests.

**According to the Third National Communication of Brazil to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (Brazil, 2016, p.186), when converting forest for agricultural or livestock use, the rate of 12% of the original biomass is removed in the form of commercial wood, such as wood for the production of charcoal, or for use as fuel for various purposes. The rest is usually left in the field and burned. 

***According to IPCC (2006, v4 p2.43), the Combustion Factor is calculated in function of the size and architecture of the fuel load (i.e., a smaller proportion of large, coarse fuel such as tree stems will be burnt compared to fine fuels, such as grass leaves), the moisture content of the fuel and the type of fire (i.e., intensity and rate of spread which is markedly affected by climatic variability and regional differences. The CF values came from Brazil (2016, Table 3.112, p.186/187), and are weighted averages for the biomes of the states.

flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value: 72.96 (MJ/m3) * VEG / NPP / 0.47 (ratio C to biomass*)  / 580 (kg/m3).

*Brazil (2016, Tab A1.7, p.244) presents the value of 47% for all carbon pools considered in forests (AGB, BGB, DOM) for Brazilian forests.

flow.name: diesel, burned in building machine
flow.category: F:Construction/43:Specialized construction activities/431:Demolition and site preparation/4312:Site preparation

defaultProvider.name: market for diesel, burned in building machine | diesel, burned in building machine | Cutoff, U
defaultProvider.category: F:Construction/43:Specialized construction activities/431:Demolition and site preparation/4312:Site preparation

exchanges.description: Calculated: The time required for the clear cutting is estimated to be two weeks (Jungbluth et al., 2007)

flow.name: Occupation, construction site
flow.category: Elementary flows/Resource/land

exchanges.description: Calculated Value: The entire biomass (either burned or degraded) is multiplied with the emission factor. No wood from clear-cutting is considered harvested. In the case of carbon emission (positive VEG value) the flux is towards the air; in cases of carbon sequestration (negative VEG value), the flux is towards the soil.

The CF values came from Brazil (2016, Table 3.112, p.186/187), and are weighted averages for the biomes of the states.

flow.name: Propylene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description:
Calculated Value: VEG / NPP / 0.47 (ratio C to biomass*) * 0.88 (fraction burned**) * CF (Combustion Factor of biome***) * EmissionFactor 

The share of VEG that is burned is multiplied with the emission factor.

*Brazil (2016, Tab A1.7, p.244) presents the value of 47% for all carbon pools considered in forests (AGB, BGB, DOM) for Brazilian forests.

**According to the Third National Communication of Brazil to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (Brazil, 2016, p.186), when converting forest for agricultural or livestock use, the rate of 12% of the original biomass is removed in the form of commercial wood, such as wood for the production of charcoal, or for use as fuel for various purposes. The rest is usually left in the field and burned. 

***According to IPCC (2006, v4 p2.43), the Combustion Factor is calculated in function of the size and architecture of the fuel load (i.e., a smaller proportion of large, coarse fuel such as tree stems will be burnt compared to fine fuels, such as grass leaves), the moisture content of the fuel and the type of fire (i.e., intensity and rate of spread which is markedly affected by climatic variability and regional differences. The CF values came from Brazil (2016, Table 3.112, p.186/187), and are weighted averages for the biomes of the states.

flow.name: Ethylene
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/low population density

exchanges.description: Calculated value: above and below ground biomass, in kg C per reference flow. In the case of carbon emission (positive VEG value) the flux is from the soil and biomass; in cases of carbon sequestration (negative VEG value), the flux is from the air.

exchanges.description: Calculated Value: considering 15 MJ/kg (17% moisture wet basis) and 45% C in dry wood, 40 MJ/kg C in wood. 15 MJ is taken to reflect UHV rather than LHV.
